Authors:
Gerald F. Bills, Victor Gonzalez, Gonzalo Platas, Marc
Stadler, Jacques Fournier
Title:
Hypoxylon pulicidum sp. nov. (Ascomycota, Xylariales), a
Pantropical Insecticide-Producing Endophyte
Abstract:
Nodulisporic acids (NAs) are novel indole diterpenes
exhibiting potent systemic efficacy against blood-feeding arthropods,
e.g.Â bedbugs, fleas and ticks via binding to arthropod specific
glutamate-gated chloride channels. Intensive medicinal chemistry efforts
employing a nodulisporic acid A template has led to the development of
N-tert-butyl nodulisporamide as a product candidate for a once monthly
treatment of fleas and ticks on companion animals. The natural source of
the NAs is a monophyletic lineage of asexual endophytic fungal strains
that is widely distributed in the tropics and that has been tentatively
identified as a Nodulisporium species and hypothesized to be the asexual
state of a Hypoxylon species. Inferences from GenBank sequences
indicated that multiple researchers have encountered the same
Nodulisporium endophytes in tropical plants and in air samples.
Ascomata-derived cultures from a wood-inhabiting fungus, collected in
Martinique and closely resembling Hypoxylon investiens, belonged to the
same monophyletic clade. The hypothesis that the Martinque Hypoxylon
collections were the sexual state of the NAs-producing endophytes was
tested by mass spectrometry of metabolite profiles, multi-gene
phylogenetic analysis, and phenotypic comparisons of the conidial
states. We established that these Hypoxylon strains produced a full
spectrum of NAs and were conspecific with the pantropical Nodulisporium
endophytes. A new species, H. pulicidum, is proposed to accommodate this
widespread cryptic organism. Reconstructing cryptic endophyte life
cycles is critical to the understanding of their dispersal to and
colonization of plants. Knowledge of the life cycle of H. pulicidium
will facilitate an understanding of the role of insecticide compounds
produced by the fungus and how it survives in living and dead plants.
Over three decades of endophyte research has revealed that endophytic
fungi are hyperdiverse and that the gap between their discovery and the
capacity to name and classify them is ever widening. Elucidating the
life cycle of H. pulicidum raises reservations about recent proposals to
instate environmental sequenced-based species designations and the
doubtful practice of applying formal scientific names to vegetative
endophyte isolates.
